messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 19, 2018 - December 25, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-12-27T02:04:01Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-12-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181227-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may have a glancing impact at Spitzer, STEREO A, and Parker Solar Probe.  The flank of the CME is simulated to reach Spitzer at 2018-12-27T06:33Z, STEREO A at 2018-12-27T02:46Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2018-12-26T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-12-23.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~600km/s on 2018-12-24.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)                     
2018-12-24T07:12Z     ~588            C              -115/-5                24                          SOHO, STEREO A                    

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-01-01T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are some small active regions on the solar surface that could have some flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming period due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-12-28.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 12, 2018 - December 18, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-12-19T21:12:31Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-12-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181219-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-12-07, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed   

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-12-25T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are a couple of small active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.
 
## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for December 05, 2018 - December 11, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-12-12T17:41:44Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-05T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-12-11T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181212-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-12-09T21:00Z-24:00Z.  The slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-12-07. Solar wind speed reached values of ~650 km/s on 2018-12-10.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES were elevated at the end of the reporting period, but remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-12T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-12-18T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are a couple of small active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flare or CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-12-15.
 
## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for November 28, 2018 - December 04, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-12-05T18:33:31Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-11-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-12-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20181205-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.    

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-12-02T21:00Z-24:00Z. The slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-12-01. Solar wind speed reached values of ~470 km/s on 2018-12-03.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of coronal hole high speed streams around 2018-12-01. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-12-02.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

None Observed

None Observed

None Observed

## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-12-05T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-12-11T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are a couple of small active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flare or CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-12-07.


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
